loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Like other business persons, Agnes C. also dreams of success in her grocery business. She started it off small, using her savings of Php 3,000 in 1986. She managed it well and has turned it into a mini-grocery. This year, she is earning a lot from her store and what she wants to do is to send her two children to college.

However, she still needs capital to buy additional merchandise for her store. She is asking for a loan of Php 25,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. The loan will really help her achieve better income for her family.

She is happy with the services of CEVI. She still would like to access loans, training and insurance coverage as well from them.

loans.use: To purchase assorted groceries for sale

loans.name: Sor

texts.en:
Sor K., 43, has been involved in the agriculture sector as a rice farmer and growing other crops with a typical income of US $0.50 per day in Takeo Province since 1980. K. and her husband work very hard every day to ensure a comfortable standard of living for the family. Her husband and K. are blessed with two children; one of them is enrolled in a local high school while the other one is employed in a garment factory. Her husband is a blacksmith in the town with a typical income of US $6 per day.

K. really wants to take a loan of US $700 to purchase a motorbike to operate another business of transporting potatoes she grows to sell at the local markets. By doing this, she hopes that she will be able to generate a better income to cover her family expenses as well as for savings to support her child’s future education.

loans.use: purchasing a motorbike

loans.name: Ou

texts.en:
Ou L., 43, has been involved in producing a popular Cambodian snack, earning a gross income of US $11 per day in Takeo Province since 1980. L. and her husband work very hard every day to ensure a comfortable standard of living for the family. Her husband and L. are blessed with two children who are stereo repairmen. Her husband is a local priest for any special ceremonies in his village and other nearby places, with a typical income of US $5 per day.

L. really wants to take a loan of US $600 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to travel more easily and faster to the faraway places for his business. By doing this, she hopes that she will be able to have savings to cover her family expenses.

loans.use: purchasing a motorbike

loans.name: Oum

texts.en:
Oum S., 41, has been involved in a business of selling firewood with a typical income of US $1.30 per day in Takeo Province since 2005. S. and her husband work very hard every day to ensure a comfortable standard of living for the family. She and her husband are blessed with a lovely young child who has not enrolled in school yet. Her husband is employed with a construction building company with a typical income of US $4.60 per day.

S. really wants to take a loan of US $700 to purchase cows to raise for sale and to help her in farming with her rice fields. By doing this, she hopes that she will be able to generate a better income to cover her family expenses as well as for savings to support her child’s future education.

loans.use: buying cows

loans.name: Muth

texts.en:
Muth C., 54, has been involved in a business of selling beans with a typical income of US $1.66 per day in Takeo Province since 2008. C. and her husband work very hard every day to ensure a comfortable standard of living for the family. Her husband and C. are blessed with four children; two of them are enrolled in a local high school while the other two are employed in a garment factory. Her husband is a motorbike repairman in the town with a typical income of US $5 per day.

C. really wants to take out a loan of US $600 to purchase motorbike and bicycle spare parts to have on hand to replace parts for her husband’s customers’ motorbikes and bicycles when theirs get broken. By doing this, she hopes that she will be able to generate a better income to cover her family expenses as well as for savings to support her children’s future education.

loans.use: motorbike spare parts

loans.name: Keneth Joy

texts.en:
Keneth Joy A. is a direct seller of fashion products. She opened a store to display new dresses, accessories for girls, perfumes, and many more. She already have a sari-sari store (retail shop) that is why is easy for her to sell the fashion products that she deals to customers. She started her business in 2002. Until now, she is doing the same thing because she finds it a profitable business to maintain.

She needs additional capital  for her business. This is the reason why she intends to apply for a loan worth Php 25,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). The loan will help a lot in buying additional fashion and store merchandise that hopefully will attract more people  to visit her store.

She would still like to access CEVI's services in the future. She has received loans, training and insurance coverage from CEVI.

loans.use: To purchase assorted clothing, accessories, and store merchandise

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a member of the Mtazamo borrower group in Msamvu, Morogoro. She is a 46-year-old woman; she is married, and mother of 2 children. Her children are aged 22 and 17. She also cares for 1 other dependent.

Grace started her own farm supplies business selling wheat 7 years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 450,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Grace’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 400,000 Tsh in order to expand her business. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Grace hopes to make repairs, save money, get more food for her family, pay school fees, and expand her business.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Dal Jan Group

texts.en: D. Jan is the group leader of D. Jan group. There are four members in this group who all want to expand and grow their businesses. D. Jan wants a loan to open a new shop for her carpet weaving business. M. Nazer will use the loan to expand his metal working shop. Merza Ahmad will use the loan for his vegetable business and Khatera for her tailoring business. They would all like to say this loan is very useful because it provides a good opportunity for poor entrepreneurs to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en:
Mary Jean H. is a 37-year-old store owner and rice retailer in Sto. Nino, South Cotabato Mindanao. She has been selling various goods in her store. Because rice is a much-purchased commodity, she started selling rice in her store as well, to augment their family income.

She is requesting a loan worth Php 25,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. The loan will go far in buying the additional merchandise to grow her business.

She chose CEVI for its wide services. CEVI helps their clients sustain and grow their livelihood. Aside from loans, it also gives training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase assorted groceries

loans.name: Mdawi-2 Group

texts.en:
Neema is a member of the "Mdawi-2"  borrower group in Kiborilon, Kilimanjaro. She is a 28-year-old woman; she is married and the mother of 1 child. Her child is 3 years old. She also cares for 1 other dependent. 

Neema started her own business selling shoes and fabric 2 years ago. She works 8 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 150,000 Tanzania Schillings.

This is Neema’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more shoes and fabric. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Neema hopes to save money and expand her business. 

Fortunata, another member of the "Mdawi-2" borrower group, has also requested 200,000 Tsh in order to support her own business of selling vitenge and kanga (kinds of traditional fabric).

Oliva, also a member of the same group, requested 200,000 Tsh in order to support her business.

loans.use: To buy more shoes

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en:
It was in May 1994 that Michelle E. and her husband started a small hatchery business. They can still remember the time when they were making “balut”(egg delicacy) themselves, never worrying about the risk of biking at night, to sell their eggs for income for their family. Every day, they toil away because they like to earn enough to have savings to add to their capital. They also ensure good quality of their product and services to please their customers and sustain their business. Their experiences are really a mixture of perseverance, hard work and prayer that they continuously do until today.

Presently, the couple are the proprietors of the largest “Balut” and hatchery business in Sto. Nino, South Cotabato, Mindanao. “ Balut” is a very popular delicacy in the Philippines. It is made of duck and chicken eggs. Making the eggs as their business, the couple is sure that they will have a stable income their family will enjoy.

Aiming for business growth to support their child's education, the couple finally joined the credit program of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. Their participation in the program was an opportunity to learn about savings and business management. During cluster meetings, they were able to market and talk about their product to other entrepreneurs who were also accessing CEVI credit services. The couple markets their eggs as well as their ducklings, always for sale.

Over years of business development, their loan of Php 4,000 from CEVI has gone far in acquiring business assets. Seventy percent of their income is reinvested in the business and the rest goes to savings.

“Some of our competitors have tried destroying us as well as our business. They are after our regular customers. Good that they never succeeded. God has helped us survive and stay in the market for so many years now. We are doing our best to make our business grow even more. In that way we would be able to employ more people in our business,” they said. The business has now reached Davao and General Santos (still part of Mindanao). They opened an outlet in these cities, hoping that more and more “Balut vendors” will be able to benefit from their high quality but less expensive eggs. Surprisingly, their business has turned everyone on to sell eggs in the streets to have a livelihood for their children.

Aside from the hatchery business, they have now started distributing fashion products. This business also helps them supplement their income. They hope that like their hatchery business, their engagement in fashion retail will also be a success.

Until now, the couple continues to access loans through the CEVI credit program. They like the services of CEVI because they also teach people with businesses moral standards and Christian faith. The couple believes in God, who is the center of their business success. They believe that God will always bless the works of the faithful. And with all accomplishments and compliments they receive, they will remain humble and continue to help their community, especially those who seek their aid.

Having learned about KIVA from CEVI, Michelle E. would like to borrow Php 25,000. She will use the loan to improve their business.

loans.use: to purchase eggs for sale

loans.name: Riza Joy

texts.en:
Riza Joy R. is managing a small sari-sari store business. She is 35 years old and has four children. She started selling in 2000 using her savings of Php 5,000 as start-up capital. Her business is situated in the town public market. From her experience, she was able to establish a network of regular buyers of her merchandise.

She wants to apply for a loan worth Php 25,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use her loan to purchase assorted groceries and rice. She believes these will help increase her income.

Riza is happy that she is part of the CEVI credit program. She has learned many things from the cluster meetings that are held every week. She has received not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well from CEVI.

loans.use: To purchase assorted groceries and rice for sale

loans.name: Nakasero South Serunjogi Rukia Group

texts.en:
S. Rukia is a married woman of forty-seven and the leader of her group. She is blessed with six children, of whom one child is still going to school, and she is looking after four siblings who are also going to school.

Rukia deals in poultry and has been in this business so far for eight years. Rukia is using the loan to purchase and add chicks mostly broilers, feed, chicken drugs, chicks for rearing. She wants to maintain healthy poultry for sale. She is a hard-working woman whose business dream is to purchase more chicks especially layers and expand her poultry business.

loans.use: add chicks (mostly broilers) and buy feed, chicken drugs, chicks for rearing

texts.en:

Neema started her own clothing business selling blouses 3 years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 150,000 Tanzania Schillings.

This is Habiba's first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to expand her business. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Habiba hopes to save money, pay school fees, and expand her business.

Venisia, another member of the Majengo Miembeni borrower group, has also requested 200,000 Tsh in order to support her own clothing business.

Alisi, also a member of the same group, requested 200,000 Tsh in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Terisita

texts.en:
Terisita H. is from the village of Militar, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 49 years old. Terisita is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Terisita owns and operates a sari-sari or general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Terisita has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Terisita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Terisita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Terisita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Terisita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Buguma Batega Hawa Group

texts.en: B. Hawa is a leader of Baguma Women's group. She is thirty-six years old, married with five children of whom four are going to school. She is looking after four dependents of whom two are schooling. She deals with poultry rearing, and she has been in this busines for five years. She needs medicines for her poultry; she also needs feeds, etc. Therefore she is using this loan to purchase chicks to add to the number of poultry she has, feed, and drugs for her poultry. She is a hard-working and courageous business lady whose dream is to obtain a motorcycle for daily income generation.

loans.use: To purchase chicks to add to the number of poultry she has, also feed and drugs for her poultry

texts.en:

Veronica started her own shop business selling bananas, coconuts, and potatoes 7 years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 200,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Veronica’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more bananas, coconuts and potatoes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Veronica hopes to save money, expand her business, and pay school fees.

Nestor has been engaged in his business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay his children's tuition fees. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a 40 year old woman married to Maleno, a laborer, and they have four children ranging in age from 14-9. They live in a rural but very beautiful village of Hamtic in the Antique province in the Philippines. She has had her business since 2005 of selling vegetables in her village, but it was hard to gain extra capital to buy more goods and be able to increase her profit.

With this loan from ASHI of 12,000 Pesos, she will be able to buy a larger quantity of vegetables and also is going to buy a few small piglets for pig fattening, a popular business here. She will buy them seed, supplements and vitamins and sell them after about six months when they are ready to go to market.

Her greatest hope is to rise out of poverty. With more of her vegetables in production and this extra source of income from the hogs, she believes she will be able to save money to send her kids to school and hopefully one day college.

Written by Sloane Berrent, Kiva Fellow

loans.use: To buy piglets and vegetables.

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita D. is from the town of Tamban Pta. Miray, Baliangao. She is 29 years old, married, with 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Anecita owns and operates a business venture in the food sector operating a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Anecita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Anecita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anecita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from PMPC. Anecita is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase a fishing boat. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Anecita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing boat.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene N. is from the village of Landing. She is 38 years old and married. To make a living, Arlene owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling sari-sari (small convenience store) products in the local community. Arlene has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Arlene joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arlene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,500 PHP from PMPC. Arlene is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to fully pay for a motorcycle as a means of transportation, which aids their present business. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Arlene from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle.

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida is a 44-year-old woman married to Ethlebert, a laborer, and they have eight children ranging in age from 22-4 years old. They live in Pandan, a beautiful coastal town in the north of Antique province. When she started her business three years ago, it was just a small capital to buy and sell rice for consumption. With every loan, she is able to expand just a little bit more. With this loan of 22,000 Pesos, she is going to buy 60 sacks of rice to sell in smaller quantities. She is going to buy two piglets and the feed and vitamins they need to go strong and fat and be ready for market.

On the side, she has also started a manicure business where she goes to her neighbors to give them manicures and pedicures. This is good for her and her family because if the weather is bad or typhoons hit, she has more than one way to keep an income.

Her hope is to be able to save enough to help all of her children finish school. She's like to help her husband open a store of his own and hopefully one day build a big enough house for all her children to be able to live there to. For Nida, family is always the most important thing.

Written by Sloane Berrent, Kiva Fellow

loans.use: Buying and selling of rice, hog fattening and possibly supporting her manicure business

loans.name: Kafule B Sarah Naaku Group

texts.en: Sarah N. is a single business lady and the leader of her group. She is blessed with two children who go to school. She has been operating a retail shop business for over four years. She is using the loan to purchase items such as sugar, soap, salt, biscuits, cooking oil, flour, sodas, etc., in order to add more stock to her business. She is a hardworking lady whose dream is to obtain poultry.

loans.use: To purchase items such as sugar, soap, salt, biscuits, cooking oil, flour, sodas, etc.

loans.name: Hilda Luz

texts.es: Hilda Luz P. D. Z. resiD. en el cantón Joya GranD. del municipio D. Apopa. Hilda tiene 41 años D. edad y es madre cuatro hijos dos D. ellos ya trabajan y aportan a la casa un promedio D. US 200$ mensuales y los otros dos hijos D. Hilda aun se encuentran estudiando. Hilda se dedica a la elaboración D. tortillas todos los días por las tardes y también posee una venta D. pupusas, todo esto dentro D. su casa, el crédito que solicita Hilda es para la compra D. un refrigerador ya que es necesario para guardar los materiales que utiliza para hacer pupusas porque D. otra manera se descomponen si no se encuentran en refrigeración, D. esta manera Hilda ya no molestaría mas a sus vecinas para que le guarden sus alimentos por que con el crédito, ella al fin lograría tener un refrigerador en su casa.
texts.en:
Hilda Luz P. D. Z. lives in the Joya GranD. district of the town of Apopa. She is 41 years old and the mother of 4 children. Two of her children are already working and earning an average of $200 USD per month, while the other two children are students. Hilda makes tortillas every evening and she also runs a business selling pupusas (flatbread stuffed with meat, cheese, or vegetables). She operates both businesses out of her home.

Hilda will use her loan to buy a refrigerator in order to preserve the ingredients used for making pupusas, since those items can decompose if not stored properly. This will also prevent Hilda from bothering her neighbors and asking them to store food items for her. With the loan, she will finally have a refrigerator in her house.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients & a refrigerator

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is a member of the Nyamhanga borrower group in Ruaha, Iringa. She is a 25 year old woman, married, and the mother of 2 children. Her children are aged 3 and 1, and she also cares for 2 other dependents.
 
Anna started her own shop selling sugar and soap 1 year ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 50,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Anna’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 300,000 Tsh in order to to buy more commodities for her shop. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Anna hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities.

loans.name: Irma

texts.es: Irma H. Vda. D. R. resiD. en el municipio D. apopa del departamento D. San Salvador. Irma tiene 52 años D. edad Vive con dos hijos: Melquíades D. 19 años y una hija D. 25 años. Irma se dedica a ala elaboración y venta D. tortillas todos los días y por las tardes elabora antojitos que no pueden faltar en la merienda D. los salvadoreños, Irma posee una clientela muy estable ya que ella lleva años trabajando y es muy conocida en la zona, el crédito que Irma solicita es para la compra D. materia prima para sus antojitos ya que desea aumentar su producción e ir a ofrecer a mas lugares para lograr mayores ingresos.
texts.en:
Irma lives in the municipality of Apopa in the department of San Salvador. She is 52 years old with two children: Melquiades, age 19, and a daughter, age 25. Irma is engaged in the making and selling of tortillas every day, and in the afternoons she makes small snacks that people in El Salvador cannot do without.

Irma has a very stable clientele since she has been working for years and is well known in the area. The loan that Irma is applying for is for the purchase of basic materials since she wants to increase her production and offer them in more places in order to succeed in obtaining greater income

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of basic materials

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es: Carlos M. V. reside en el municipio de mejicanos del departamento de San Salvador. Carlos tiene 43 años de edad, vive con su esposa y tres hijos de los cuales dos aun se encuentran estudiando y solo uno trabaja. Carlos posee un negocio de reparación de relojes y venta de accesorios para los mismos, el destino del crédito que solicita Carlos es para la compra de mercadería para su negocio ya que desea adquirir de más variedad en accesorios y también para la compra de beterías que se utilizan para los relojes.
texts.en:
Carlos M. V. lives in the Mejicanos municipality in the San Salvador department. Carlos, 43, lives with his wife and three children. Two of his children are still in school; only one works. Carlos has a watch repair business, and he sells accessories for the watches. The loan that Carlos is asking for is to buy merchandise for his business. He wants to have a bigger variety of accessories, and he also wants to buy watch batteries.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy watch accessories and batteries

loans.name: Tomas

texts.en:
Tomas S. is a 32 year old farmer from Sto. Nino South Cotabato Mindanao. He is a father of three children and a rice grower in their village. He started farming in 1994 using a 1-hectare farm that he rented. His dream is that someday he will have his own farm to till, and he will be able to support his children's education.

He is asking for a loan of PHP 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to purchase fertilizers and chemicals. The loan will help him grow his harvest and fulfill his dreams for the future.

He is actively participating in the CEVI cluster meetings held every week. He is also happy with the training and insurance coverage provided by CEVI.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals.

loans.name: Ezequiel

texts.es: Ezequiel R. H. reside en San Luis Talpa en el departamento de La Paz. Ezequiel tiene 48 años de edad, vive solamente con su hijo Federico de 16 años quien se encuentra estudiando. Ezequiel es un padre muy trabajador y responsable con su único hijo ha logrado sostener dos negocios para poder generar mayores ingresos;  se desempeña como sastre y también posee un chalet  dentro de un centro escolar, Ezequiel solicita un crédito porque  quiere invertir en su negocio surtiéndolo de mas productos para sus fieles clientes alumnos y docentes de la escuela
texts.en:
Ezequiel R. H. lives in San Luis Talpa in the La Paz department. Ezequiel, 48, lives with his 16 year old son, Federico. Federico is in school. Ezequiel is a hard working and responsible father. With his only son he has been able to sustain two businesses in order to generate greater earnings. He works as a tailor, and he also has a kiosk located inside of a school center. Ezequiel is asking for a loan because he wants to invest in his business by stocking it with more products for his loyal customers, the students and teachers in the school.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock his business

loans.name: Emely

texts.en:
Emely F.'s dream is to have a good life for herself and her children. She has a business cooking and selling food in her eatery. She is a 44 year old mother of one child. All she wants to do is develop her business even more to provide her child with a brighter future. 

She is asking for a loan of PHP 12,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase spices, beverages, vegetables and meat for her eatery business. The loan will really help her sustain the livelihood that she has had since 2000.

Now, she actively participates in CEVI cluster meetings held weekly in their village. She avails herself of CEVI credit services, and receives training and insurance coverage from them as well.

loans.use: To purchase spices, beverages, vegetables and meat for her eatery business.

loans.name: Walter Balmore

texts.es: Walter Balmore A. A. reside en el departamento de Ahuachapán. Walter tiene tan solo 19 años de edad pero su deseo de salir adelante y darle una familia  a su esposa Esmeralda lo ha hecho montar un negocio hace dos años, un taller de automotriz ubicado en la carretera Panamericana la cual es muy transitada y le permite que muchas personas conozcan su negocio, el crédito que solicita Walter es para comprar repuestos utilizados para los vehículos.
texts.en:
Walter Balmore A. A. lives in the Ahuachapán department. Walter is only 19, but his desire to get ahead and make a family with his wife, Esmeralda, caused him to start a business two years ago. He has an automotive shop, which is located on the Panamerican highway. It is a very busy highway, and a lot of people know his business. The loan that Walter is asking for is to buy replacement parts for the vehicles.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy vehicle replacement parts

loans.name: Rolando

texts.en:
In 2002, Rolando M. decided to start a small business. Since he knew a little about electronics repair, he started a shop, in order to provide income for his family. He is 44 years old this year and all of his four children are studying in school. 

All he wants to do is make his shop prosper. After he found out about Kiva in CEVI, he applied for a loan worth PHP 18,000 to support his business.

Now, he is actively joining other entrepreneurs in the village during CEVI cluster meetings. He received not just a loan but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase materials and tools for his shop.

loans.name: Zonia Elizabeth

texts.es: Zonia Elizabeth C. D. U.  resiD. en el  Barrio Santa Anita ubicado en el departamento D.  San Salvador. Zonia tiene 38 años D. edad, vive con su esposo y sus tres hijos aun menores D. edad que se encuentran estudiando. Zonia posee un negocio donD. venD. tortillas todas las tardes y también venD. variedad D. productos lácteos como queso y crema; el negocio D. Zonia se encuentra ubicado en su casa la cual queda a orilla D. calle y le permite que muchas personas puedan ver su negocio y comprar allí. Zonia solita un crédito para comprar mayor cantidad D. lácteos ya que sus ventas lo demandan y también compra D. materia prima para sus tortillas ya que desea aumentar su producción.
texts.en:
Zonia Elizabeth C. D. U. lives in the neighborhood of Santa Anita located in the department of San Salvador. Zonia is 38 years old and lives with her husband and their three children, who are still minors and go to school.

Zonia owns a store where she sells tortillas and various dairy products like cheese and cream. She opens her store every afternoon. It is located in her home right next to the street, which enables many people to see it and buy there. Zonia applies for a loan to buy a larger quantity of dairy products to meet her customers’ demand and also to buy ingredients to make tortillas, since she wants to increase her production.

Translated from Spanish by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase dairy products and ingredients to make tortillas

loans.name: Juan Emilio

texts.es: Juan Emilio C. P. de 40 años de edad reside en el municipio de Ilobasco del departamento de Cabañas. Juan vive con su madre, su esposa y tres hijos aun menores de edad, Juan posee un negocio en el cual ha dedicado la mitad de su vida, es un taller de  estructuras metálicas con veinte años de existencia, el cual le ha dado la experiencia  y la buena fama que hoy tiene, en el taller de Juna se elabora todo tipo de producción en lamina y hierro, como canales de agua para casas y graneros. Juan solicita un crédito por que lo han contratado para un proyecto para la elaboración de muchos canales para una galera que se encuentra en construcción, es por eso que necesita este crédito para la compra de materia prima utilizada en la elaboración de todos los canales que le han solicitado, de esta manera el logaría obtener este proyecto que le dejara buenas ganancias.
texts.en:
Juan Emilio C. P. is 40 years old and lives in the municipality of Ilobasco in the department of Cabañas. He lives with his mother, his wife and their three children who are still minors.

Juan owns a business in which he has spent half his life. It is a workshop for metal construction which has existed for 20 years. It has given him the experience and good reputation that he enjoys today. He executes all kind of iron production and lamination, like water and drain pipes for houses and barns. Juan applies for this loan because he has been offered to participate in a construction project of a gallery with many pipes. He needs this loan to buy raw materials, so that he can succeed in securing this assignment which will yield a good profit.

Translated from Spanish by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials

loans.name: Candelaria Lissette

texts.es: Candelaria Lissette T. S. de 25 años de edad reside en el departamento de La Libertad junto a sus padres, hermana y dos hijas Johana de 11 años y Yadira de 4 años de edad. Hace un año Candelaria se ve en la necesidad de poner un negocio ya que por su nivel de educación se le hace muy difícil conseguir un trabajo con un buen salario y es cuando a Candelaria se le ocurrió la idea de poner una tienda, al observar que no hay ninguna en la zona vio que sería un buen negocio, y efectivamente es así Candelaria ha tenido buena aceptación por sus vecinos ya que posee excelente ventas ; es por eso que ahora está dispuesta a invertir en su negocio para lo cual necesita de un crédito ya que desea surtir su negocio para seguir aprovechando lo bien que le va en su tienda.
texts.en:
Candelaria Lissette T. S. is 25 years old and lives in the department of La Libertad together with her parents, her sister and her two daughters, Johana aged 11 and Yadira aged 4.

A year ago, Candelaria understood that she needed her own store, as she had great difficulties to get a job with a good salary due to her education level. She realized that there was no other store in her area, and indeed she was well accepted by her neighbors who ensured her an excellent turnover. Today, Candelaria is ready to invest more in her store. That’s why she needs a loan to increase her inventory and take advantage of her continued success.

Translated from Spanish by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To supply her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase the needed materials and equipment for tailoring.

loans.name: Zaina

texts.en:
Zaina is a member of the Nyamhanga C borrower group in Ruaha, Iringa. She is a 20 year old woman, married, and the mother of one child who is 1 year old.

Two years ago, Zaina started her own business selling clothes. She works 10 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 100,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Zaina's first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 300,000 Tsh in order to to buy more clothes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Zaina hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Stocking his store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and other equipment for tailoring business.

loans.name: Aisha's Group

texts.en: Aisha N. is the leader of Twezimbe group in Kayunga. She is 40 years of age, a mother of 4 children, and she also cares for 4 orphaned grandchildren. Aisha is a business woman who sells dried fish that she buys from the landing sites at Kayunga and Lugazi, and then sells from her home in Kyabakadde. She has had her business for 3 years and has been a member of her group for over 5 years. Her previous business was farming. She helps her husband pay school fees for her children from the profits of her business and she is happy that she does what she does. Aisha needs a loan to buy more fish for resale.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Athe

texts.fr: Athe B. est âgé de 43 ans, marié et père de 4 enfants. il réside à Adeta où il exerce le commerce des fruits. Son activité consiste à payer les marchandises auprès des agriculteurs et de les amener dans la capitale pour la revente. Ce commerce est très florissant à cause de la forte demande et de la faible concurrence. Avec ce crédit, il souhaite accroître la capacité de son activité.
texts.en:
Athe B., 43 years old, is married with 4 children. He lives in Adeta, where he works as a fruit vender. He purchases fruits from growers, then takes them to the capital for resale. It's a flourishing business, because demand is high and there isn't much competition. With this loan, he expects to increase his productive capacity.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fruit for resale.

loans.name: Farid

texts.en:
This young man, Farid, was born in 1988. He lives in Baku city. This single man has three years of experience in the clothing-sales business. 

Farid plans to also sell foodstuffs and juices. He does not want to sell only clothes. This man thinks that if he varies his goods, he can get more income and that is why he applies for the loan of 2,000 AZN.

loans.use: To buy goods

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline J. manages a small sari-sari (variety) store business. She is married to Loreto J., a rice grower, and has one child. She started the store in 1995. She keeps doing the same thing because she finds it a profitable business to do.

She needs additional capital for her business. She is asking for a loan worth Php 16,000. She will use the loan to purchase additional merchandise for her store.

Now, she is actively participating in the CEVI credit program. She receives not just loans but also training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise for her store

loans.name: Kinegamgosi  A Group

texts.en:
Auleliya is a member of the Kinegamgosi A borrower group in Ruaha, Iringa. She is a 34-year-old woman who is married and the mother of four children. Her children are ages 13, 9, 6 and 3. She also cares for two other dependents. 

Auleliya started her own grocery business selling local alcohol six years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 150,000 Tanzania Schillings (about $113).

This is Auleliya’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to expand her business. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Auleliya hopes to save money, get more food for her family and expand her business. 

Subira, another member of the Kinegamgosi A borrower group, has also requested 200,000 Tsh in order to support her own grocery business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Johakina

texts.en:
Johakina is a member of the Kinegamsosi A borrower group in Ruaha, Iringa. She is a 48-year-old widowed mother of three children. Her children are ages 24, 18 and 16. 
 
Johakina started her own grocery business selling local alcohol six years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 120,000 Tanzania Shillings (about $90).

This is Johakina’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 Tsh in order to to buy more maize for her business. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Johakina hopes to save money, get more food for family and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more maize

loans.name: Edward's Group

texts.en: Edward K. is the leader of Zibula Atudde group in Mityana. He is a hard working and devoted member of his lending group. Edward has had a produce selling business for over 10 years whereby he buys produce from fellow farmers and sells again to the traders in the various markets and trading centers. He has a store where he stocks his produce for easy access. He needs a loan to be able to buy more produce for his stock so that he will be able to make more profits that can enable him to care for his family’s needs.

loans.use: To buy more produce for resale

loans.name: Hilario

texts.en:
Hilario P. is from the village of Kiburiao, Quezon Bukidnon. He is 43 years old. Hilario is married and has school-aged children. To make a living, Hilario owns and operates a business running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Hilario has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.(Hilario was out of town during the picture taking, so we let his wife represent him, being a partner in their business.)

In 1997, Hilario joined HSPFI to have access to financial services. As to their previous loan, Helario and his wife are both happy and thankful for all the Kiva lenders who provide financial support. With this support, their business is growing and making more progress than before. They are hopeful that lenders may continue to finance their business activities. They have just ended their previous loan amounting to PHP 20,000. Hilario is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 15th loan taken out by Hilario from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family, educational expenses of the children and savings for future emergencies. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell at his shop

loans.name: Kafule B Sabika Catherine Group

texts.en: The leader of this group is 43-year-old S. Catherine. She is blessed with five children and also looks after one dependant who is in school. For 20 years, Catherine has dealt in bananas, purchasing them from villages and selling them in the town. She is using her loan to purchase bananas from the villages in much greater volume than she could previously. Catherine is an open-minded, hardworking businesswoman. Her dream is to obtain poultry to generate a side income.

loans.use: To purchase bananas in bulk

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth A. is 26 years old and married with two children. She sells VCDs and electrical bulbs. She is requesting the loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more VCDs to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more VCDs to sell

loans.name: Lyn

texts.en:
Lyn B. owns and manages a tailoring business. She is a seamstress and sells clothes to her customers, who mostly live in the nearby barrio. Lyn has six children. Her husband, Johnny, died of diabetes, so she now manages the business on her own.

Lyn is requesting a loan of 14,000 PHP from Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI). She will use the loan to purchase textiles and other materials for her dress shop. The loan will help grow her business and pay the expenses in her home.

Lyn participates in the weekly CEVI cluster meetings. She likes the services CEVI offer very much and she will continue to use them in the future.

loans.use: To purchase textiles and other materials for her dress shop

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda D. started a glassware business in 1990. She is married to Antonio, who was a delivery truck driver. She has three children who are all studying. The income that Erlinda gets from her business helps pay her children's tuition fees, and also covers the expense of books and other school needs.

Now, she needs the additional capital of 13,000 PHP, which she will use to buy assorted glassware to sell. Kiva partner CEVI helps Erlinda sustain her livelihood. She actively participates in CEVI's weekly cluster meetings. She appreciates CEVI's services, especially the loans, training and insurance cover.

loans.use: To purchase assorted glassware for sale

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira O. is from the village of Lantay, Valencia Bukidnon. She is 40 years old. Elvira is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Elvira owns and operates a furniture-making business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Elvira has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elvira joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elvira is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools and other equipment to expand the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Elvira from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools and other equipment to expand the business

loans.name: Kafule A. Nalumisa Prossy Group

texts.en: N. Prosy is a single business lady and leader of her group. She has been dealing in used clothing and new clothing since 2002. She has only meager capital and now she is requesting this loan to purchase more clothing to add to her stock for more profits. She is blessed with two children who are going to school and she also looks after three dependents, also going to school. She is a hard-working woman whose dream is to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing to add to her stock for more profit

loans.name: Christian

texts.en: Christian J. is 58 years old and married with 6 children. She sells sarongs and bags in the market. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more sarongs and bags to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and bags to sell

loans.name: Kafule A Monica Mayaja Group

texts.en:
Monica M. is a promissory business lady representing her group. She is thirty-five years old. Monica M. is widowed with four children, all at school, and she is taking care of two dependents, also going to school. She has been in the poultry business for over ten years.

Her stock is down and that is why she is requesting the loan to purchase more chicks, buy chicken feed, and drugs for quality poultry. She wants her stock to improve so that she can get good profits. She is a promising business lady whose dream is to build rental houses for income generation to help her children in future.

loans.use: Purchasing more chicks, buying chicken feed and drugs for quality poultry

loans.name: Ogbonnaya

texts.en: Ogbonnaya is 42 years old. He is married with 4 children. He sells zobo drinks. Zobo is a locally made drink in Nigeria. He hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more zobo ingredients to make more zobo drinks to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more zobo ingredients

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is 53 years old and married with seven children who are in school. He lives in Ibadan. Peter is requesting the loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more stationery to sell. He sends his thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more stationery to sell

loans.name: Christy

texts.en: Christy E. is 58 years old and married with four children. She sells sarongs of various colors. She is asking for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell.  She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase sarongs

loans.name: Eniola

texts.en: Eniola is a 56-year-old widow with one child. She sells cooked foods and drinks. She is requesting the loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Rose Marilyn

texts.en:
Rose Marilyn S. is from the city of Dapitan. She is 40 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Rose Marilyn owns and operates a business in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from her husband providing carpentry services to local community members. Rose Marilyn has had her business for over eight years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Rose Marilyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rose Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Rose Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase carpentry tools. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Rose Marilyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase carpentry tools

loans.name: Nsozibiri B Nakilijja Jane Group

texts.en: N. Jane is 35 years old, married, and blessed with six children and two dependents, who are all in school. She is representing her group. Jane is a farmer and she deals in livestock. She has been in this business for three years. She is using her loan to purchase feed, drugs, pumps, fertilizer, etc. for her livestock and plants. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to prosper.

loans.use: To purchase feed, drugs, pumps, fertilizer, etc. for her livestock and plants

loans.name: Funke

texts.en: Funke, from Ibadan, is 53 years old and married with three children. A seller of provisions and gift items, she is requesting the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more provisions and gift items to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and gift items to sell.

loans.name: Razim

texts.en:
Razim was born in 1975, is married and has three children. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan's Fuzuli region. He is now settled in Fuzuli region in the Garabulag village.

Five years ago, he started a cattle breeding business. Now he needs a loan of 1600 AZN to buy four calves to improve his cattle breeding business.

loans.use: To buy four calves

loans.name: Nsozibiri A Atima Fina Group

texts.en: A. Fina is the group representative; she is a 30-year-old businesswoman, married, and blessed with three children. Two of her children are going to school. She is also taking care of one dependent who is also in school. A. Fina has a silver fish business and she has been operating her business for four years. She is using the loan to purchase silver fish, adding capital to her business for much profit. She is an encouraging businesswoman whose dream is to increase her farm productivity.

loans.use: To purchasing silver fish to add capital to her business

loans.name: Oghomwen

texts.en: Oghomwen is 42 years old and she is married with five children. She sells grocery store items. She hopes for a loan in the amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more items to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase grocery store items to sell

loans.name: Karomat

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Каромат женщина 40 лет. Замужем, имеет четверых детей. Муж работает поваром в частной школе. Каромат занимается производством сахара-рафинада в домашних условиях. Она прессует в специальных формах сахарную пудру на кубики, после сушит их на стеллажах. В этом ей помогают дети. Готовую продукцию она сдаёт клиентом которые торгуют на базаре. На запрашиваемый займ Каромат хочет закупить сахарную пудру.
texts.en:
Karomat is a 40-year-old woman. She is married and has four children. Her husband works as a cook at a private school. Karomat is involved in making sugar cubes at home. She presses powdered sugar in special forms into cubes and then dries them on shelves. Her children help her with this. Karomat sells the final product to customers who sell it at a market. Karomat wants to use this loan to purchase powdered sugar.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of powdered sugar

loans.name: Tejuosho

texts.en: Tejuosho is 48 years old and married with four children. He sells welding gas. He hopes for a loan in the amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more welding gas to sell. He says thank to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more welding gas to sell

loans.name: Francisca Okunlola

texts.en: Francisca is 42 years old and married with three children. She sells drinks. Francisca lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Mai's Group

texts.en:
Mai Thị Nguyễn was born in 1973. She lives in Xom Huong, Co Loa, Dong Anh with her husband and 3 children. Her two older children are in school but the youngest children is still too young. She is a farmer. Also, she and her husband sell meat in the market. They have a monthly income of about 3.500.000 VND.

Mai is a leader of an 8-member group loan offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Mai needs a loan in the amount of 5.014.000 VND to expand her product offerings.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:
* Chung Thị Nguyễn was born in 1952. She is a farmer who breeds pigs and poultry. She has 3 children. She has a monthly income of about 3.500.000 VND. She wants to borrow 6.322.000 VND to buy food for pigs.
* Toán Thị Nguyễn was born in 1952 and she has one child. She sells paper goods and earns a monthly income of about 2.500.000 VND. She wants to borrow 4.578.000 VND to buy more paper.
*Thoa Thị K. Trương was born in 1957. She sells sundries. She wants to borrow 7.630.000 VND to invest in her store.
*Lam Thị Nguyễn was born in 1975 and has two children. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND for retailing purposes.
*Huệ Bích Nguyễn was born in 1976 has two children. She wants to borrow 6.758.000 VND to invest in her music CD shop.
*Hay Thị Vũ was born in 1968. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND (or 280 USD) to expand her product offerings.
*Phương Thị Nguyễn was born in 1971 and she has three children. She wants to borrow 6.758.000 VND to buy rice to make rice cakes.

loans.use: To expand their product offerings.

loans.name: Haydee

texts.en:
Haydee E., a 42-year-old farmer and mother of six children, is married to Armin E. Sr. who is also a farmer. She learned from her husband, starting to help on the farm in 1986, and now knows very well the whole process of growing rice from planting to harvest. She is asking for a loan of Php 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy fertilizers and chemicals. Haydee actively participates in the CEVI cluster meetings held monthly in their barrio.

CEVI provides their clients with credit assistance, training and insurance coverage services.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals.

loans.name: Agatha

texts.en:
Agatha is a member of the “Kinegamgosi A” borrower group in Ruaha, Iringa. She is a 48-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of four children. Her children are aged 27, 24, 15 and 13 years.
 
Agatha started her own clothing business twenty years ago selling used clothes. She works seven hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 150,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Agatha’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes to sell. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Agatha hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is a 32-year-old single man without children. He sells building materials. He is requesting the loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more building materials to sell. He sends his thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials to sell

loans.name: Suraiyo

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Сурайё 1971 года рождения. Замужем, мать троих детей. Сурайё портниха. Её муж тоже портной. Он занимается пошивом чехлов для машин и покраской кожаных изделий. Сурайё больше года кредитуется нашей организации. У неё в областной больнице города Худжанда есть цех. Она занимается пошивом спец. одежды для медицинского персонал. Также ей заказывают матрасы для коек больницы.Сейчас Сурайё заказали халаты и матрасы, поэтому она намерена досрочно погасить оставшуюся займ. На запрашиваемый займ она хочет закупить ткань для пошива халатов и матрасов.
texts.en:
Suraiyo was born in 1971. She is married and is a mother of three children. Suraiyo is a seamstress. Her husband is a tailor. He makes car seat covers and dyes leather goods. Suraiyo has been our client for over a year. She has a factory at the district hospital in the city of Khujand. She sews uniforms for the hospital personnel. Suraiyo also gets orders to make mattresses for the hospital beds. Suraiyo recently received orders for lab coats and mattresses; thus, she is determined to repay her remaining loan amount early. She wants to use this loan to purchase fabric for sewing the lab coats and mattresses.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie C., from the village of San Simon, Cagayan de Oro City, is a 35-year-old married mother of three school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalie owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop whose main source of income comes from selling a variety of products in the local community. Rosalie has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Rosalie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional products to sell, Rosalie is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be her fourth from HSPFI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering.

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Kiboriloni Group

texts.en:
Neema is a member of the Majengo borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 21 years old and married with one three-year-old child. Two years ago, Neema started her own business selling clothes. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 150,000 TZS. This is Neema’s first loan from Kiva partner, BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 TZS in order to buy more clothes to sell. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Neema hopes to expand her business.

Dainesi, Shamsa and Feis are also members of the same Majengo borrower group. They have also requested 200,000 TZS each in order to support their own clothing businesses.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Olusanya

texts.en: Olusanya is 43 years old and married with four children. He owns a machine that produces palm kernel oil and he also sells the chaff to livestock owners for feed. He is requesting the loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more palm kernels for making oil. He sends his thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more palm kernels for making oil

loans.name: Mamuli A Nalugenge Christina Group

texts.en:
N. Christina is the group representative of “Mamuli A”. She is forty-eight years old, and married with five children.

Christina is a farmer and, also, she raises pigs for sale. She has been in her business so far for five years. She is using the loan for purchasing pig feed, fertilizer for her farm, and so forth. She is very much encouraged with whatever she is doing and her future hope is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed, fertilizer for her farm, and so forth

loans.name: Safiu

texts.en: Safiu is 31 years old and married with four children. He has a panel-beating shop where he repairs vehicle chassis. He is requesting the loan of N100,000 to purchase more pan and steel for working. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more pans and steel for working

loans.name: Precilla

texts.en:
Precilla P. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 37 years old. Precilla is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Precilla owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling specialty food products like "bibingka" in the local community. Precilla has been engaged in her business for over 18 years and earns approximately 1000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Precilla joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Precilla has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Precilla is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Precilla from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Atakishi

texts.en:
Atakishi has been in the spare parts sales business for eight years. He was born in 1971, is married and has three children. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan's Fuzuli region. He has settled in Fuzuli region in the Bala Bahmanli village.

Now he needs a loan of 1500 AZN to buy spare parts in order to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is 48 years old and she is married with three children. She sells garri (a couscous-like grain made from grated cassava) in the market in Benin City, Edo State. She hopes for a loan in the amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase more garri to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more garri to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine B. is from the village of Lantay, Pangatucan, Valencia Bukidnon. She is 38 years old. Josephine is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns and operates a business venture in the services sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorcycle services locally termed as "habal habal" to local community members. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Josephine from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Mamuli A Nakilwa Edith Group

texts.en: N. Edith is 48 years old, married with seven children, and looking after five dependents going to school. She has a grocery business selling bananas, tomatoes and chicken. She has been in her business for 11 years. She is using the loan to purchase bananas, tomatoes and chicken for her business. The loan is adding capital to her business, which is improving in stock. Her future hope is to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase bananas, tomatoes and chicken for her business.

loans.name: Abduaziz

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Абдурахмонов Абдуазиз 1983 года рождения, женат имеет одного ребенка. Жена домохозяйка. Абдуазиз работает инспектором по надзору за трудными подростками. Свободные от работы дни он с братом ремонтируют автомашины. Он имеет свой цех по ремонту машин. У него много клиентов, так как он хороший мастер. Абдуазиз планирует расширить свою деятельность и закупить запчасти на запрашиваемый займ.
texts.en:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

Abduaziz A. was born in 1983. He is married and has one child. His wife is a housewife. Abduaziz works as an inspector to oversee difficult teenagers. During his free time from work he together with his brother repair vehicles. He has own auto repair shop. He has many customers because he is a good technician. Abduaziz plans to expand his business and buy spare parts on the requested loan.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase poultry and poultry food

loans.name: Shahnoza

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Домуллоджонова Шахноза занимается пошивом женской и мужской одежды на дому. Своё изделия она оптом сдаёт продавцам на рынке на продажу. После первого займа она расширила свой ассортимент товара и получила хорошую прибыль.У Шахнозы сейчас много заказов на летную одежду, поэтому она хочет досрочно погасить займ и планирует закупить летную ткань на пошив женских платьев и мужских сорочек. Она благодарна кредитором за поддержку её деятельности.
texts.en:
Shahnoza D. is involved in sewing women's and men's clothing at home. She sells finished products wholesale to retailers who then sell them at a market. After her first loan, Shahnoza expanded her goods selection and received a good profit. She now has many orders for summer clothing and, thus, wants to repay her loan early and plans to purchase summer fabric in order to sew women's dresses and men's shirts. She is grateful to our creditors for supporting her business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of summer fabric

loans.name: Friday

texts.en: Friday is 38 years old and he is single. He sells motor spare parts. He hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more motor spare parts to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more motor spare parts to sell

loans.name: Omiraw Group

texts.en: Omiraw is the group leader of Omiraw group. There are two members in this group. They both want loans to expand their businesses so they are requesting a group loan in the amount of 20000 Afghani. Omiraw will apply the loan to her carpet weaving business. Madina will use the loan to help with her husband's fruit and vegetable cart. They are very thankful to Kiva lenders for their support of all entrepreneurs.

loans.use: For expanding their businesses.

loans.name: Anacleta

texts.en:
Anacleta is 47-year-old woman married to Ethlebert, who is part of their local Barabgay council, and they have four teen-aged children. They live in Pandan, a beautiful coastal town in the north of Antique province. When she started her business five years ago, she had only meager capital to buy and sell rice and run a small sari sari (general) store. With every loan, she is able to expand just a little bit more. With this loan of 15,000 Pesos, she is looking to expand her business into hog fattening as well as buying supplies for her other businesses.

Anacleta's hope is to be able to save enough to help all of her children finish school. She believes she has it in her to be a successful business woman and is excited about this loan taking her one step closer to her dream. Written by Sloane Berrent, Kiva Fellow

loans.use: Hog fattening, food vending, sari sari (general store), school supplies

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul A. sells rechargeable phone cards and phone accessories. He hopes for the loan amount of N150,000 to purchase more rechargeable phone cards and phone accessories to sell. He is 30 years old and single without children. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards and phone accessories to sell

loans.name: Judith Atieno

texts.en:
Judith O. is a widow aged 24 years who has seven children. Three are her biological children, while the other four are from her late husband’s previous marriage. Six are in primary school while one is too young to start schooling.

Judith is a business lady, operating a tailoring shop at Kariobangi Market. She also sells fabric to other tailors in the same market. The business was founded by her late husband in 1990. The monthly income for her business is 30,000 Kenyan shillings ($375 U.S.)

With this loan Judith wants to open another fabric shop and hopes that the profit generated will enable her to comfortably feed and educate her children.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To increase the stock of fabrics in her tailoring shop.

loans.name: Sayeda Group

texts.en: Sayeda wants a loan for a bakery. Rowna wants a loan for a tailoring business. Sayeda is the leader of the two member Sayeda group. Each member wants to take a loan for expanding their business and they have requested a group loan of 14,000 afghani. They are thankful to AFS and Kiva lenders that are supporting poor people.

loans.use: To expand a bakery

loans.name: Loko Group

texts.en:
Here are Abie N., Fatmata M., Isatu K. and Marie C.. They call their group Loko Group, named after their tribe. This will be the first loan this group is accessing from SMT/Kiva.
