loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia C., 44, hails from the breezy highlands of Pasong Langka, Silang, Cavite (just a few miles south of Manila). She lives with her husband Larry, 46, a furniture craftsman, and their three adult children.

They have been in the furniture business for 11 years, though Amalia also makes fruits salads and sells them to neighbors when tropical fruits are in season. She earns a net income of P50,000 per month from the combined proceeds of her furniture and fruit salad businesses.

Amalia joined Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in the last quarter of 2005. She has diligently re-paid her previous loan of P27,000 and has applied for a new loan of P30,000 which she will use to purchase raw materials (wood, nails, wood adhesives, and lacquer) and tools for furniture making.

She looks forward to supplying furniture items to large stores in the city and employing the services of many craftsmen in their community.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

loans.use: Raw materials for furniture making (wood, lacquer, nails, adhesives, and tools)

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is a member of the Faraja borrower group in Msamvu, Morogoro. She is a 35-year-old woman, married, and mother of 2 children. Her children are ages 16 and 3.

Patricia started her own business selling chickens 6 years ago. She works 7 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 400,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Patricia’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 450,000 Tsh in order to buy more chickens. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Patricia hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more chickens

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina M. is a 44-year-old single mother of five children. Her eldest child is now in college. They all live together in a small house in a hilly community of Lumil, Silang, Cavite.

Life was hard for her when her husband passed away a few years ago, but she never lost hope. She worked hard and went into business. Her variety store is now three years old. She also maintains a small stall which she rents out to other entrepreneurs. Combined, she earns P 15,000 per month.

2006 was a banner year for Rosalina. It was when she joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative upon the invitation of her friends. Now, she benefits from both loans provided by the cooperative to support her business and the company of women entrepreneurs in her community.

Rosalina has applied for a new loan of P 10,000 which she will use to purchase merchandise like rice and soft drinks for her store. She looks forward to converting her small store into a large grocery store some day.

About CCT

This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

loans.name: Maricar

texts.en: Maricar R. is an entrepreneur who lives with her husband and three school-aged children in a coastal slum community north of Manila. She owns and manages a grocery store located in front of her house. Maricar has been an itinerant entrepreneur for six years. Out of her desire to move out of poverty, she worked hard at earning her customers' respect. She later owned and is now managing a small apartment which she rents out to transients. She earns Php 30,000 from the combined proceeds of the apartment rental and accumulated net sales from her grocery store. Her fervent prayer is for God to sustain her children's education through the blessings that He entrusted to her. Maricar has just finished repaying her previous loan of PHP 10,000 from CCT. She has applied for a new loan to purchase additional merchandise, like charcoal (fuel), cooking oil, and other grocery items to sell in her store. A woman with a compassionate heart, Maricar dreams of converting her small grocery store into a big supermarket someday where she can offer goods at fairly low prices to consumers and at the same help many people land a job. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal, oil, and groceries for her store

texts.en:

She has a small store in front of her home and earns around of 20,000 riels per day to contribute to her family. Rim N. says that her business is running well but she needs a loan in order to buy more essential ingredients for porridge.

Rim N. is a single mother blessed with two children: one daughter is married and one son is studying at high school. She is a determined woman who hopes to send her son to university after he graduates from high school.

Emma has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1800 PHP a month for these activities.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

After Ang S. has been planting rice, he dreams of having an ox-cart in order to transport his mature produce when the harvesting season comes. That is why he requested a loan to purchase a cart from his neighbor. This loan will provide him with a new asset.

loans.name: Chhom

texts.en:
Chhom Y., 43, is a single mother living in Battambang Province. She earns a living by raising pigs for sale. She raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. In addition, she also cultivates a rice crop.

Chhom Y. has four children; two of them are single and the other two are working (one is a vegetable seller and one works in construction).

Presently, Chhom Y. faces difficulty with transportation in that she always hires a taxi when she needs transportation. To reduce the cost of transportation, she would like a $700 loan in order to buy a new motorbike for her family's riding needs, as well as to buy a piglet to raise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Xiomara Concepción

texts.es: Xiomara Concepción M. A.  reside en el departamento de Cabañas.  Xiomara tiene 21 años de edad, vive junto a su esposo y su hijo Brandon de 4 años. Xiomara posee su propio negocio el cual se encuentra ubicado en la cochera de su casa, vende variedad de ropa para niños y adultos. El deseo de Xioamara es comprar mercadería para jóvenes ya que son los que más visitan de su local y no encuentran estilos modernos y juveniles, esto solo será posible gracias a su crédito ya que Xiomara lo destinara para surtir su negocio y generar mayores ingresos para su familia.
texts.en:
Xiomara Concepción M. A. lives in the department of Cabañas. Xiomara is 21 and lives with her husband and her 4-year-old son, Brandon. Xiomara owns her own business, which is located in her garage. She sells a variety of clothing for children and adults. Her dream is to buy merchandise for young people since those that visit her location the most aren't finding young and modern styles. This will only be possible thanks to the credit that Xiomara will put towards supplying her business and generating more income for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To supply her business

loans.name: Beverlyn

texts.en:
Beverlyn S. helps till her family's rice farm. She started farming when she got married to her husband, Jimmy S.. She is 38 years old, and she will do everything to improve their livelihood to provide for the needs of their 2 children.

She would like to ask for a loan of Php 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizers and chemicals. The loan will help the whole family sustain their business and improve their harvest.

Now, she actively participates in the CEVI cluster meeting. Through CEVI she has received loans, trainings, and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret, 50 years old and a married mother of four children, sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs. She has been in the business for a long time and hopes for the loan amount of N40000 to purchase more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs. She thanks you for the loan support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, provisions and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience, 43 years old and married with four children, sells provisions and drinks. At present she is requesting the loan amount of N60000 to purchase a grinding machine, provisions and foodstuffs.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding machine, provisions and foodstuffs.

loans.name: Uktamchon

texts.ru: Уктамчон Шамсиддинов проживает в Яванском районе. Возраст 26 лет. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Уктамчон, имеет высшее образование. Он более 2 лет работал "экономистом". В данный момент он занимается ратениводством. Он в основном выращивает овощи и продает их на рынке. Этим видом бизнеса занимается более 5 лет. Кредит просит для обработки 10га земли и повторного посева.
texts.en:
Uktamchon S. lives in the Yavan district. He is 26 years old, married and has 2 children. Uktamchon has a higher education. He worked as an economist for over 2 years. Currently, he is involved in horticulture. He primarily grows vegetables and sells them at a market. He has been involved in this business for over 5 years. He is requesting a loan for processing 10ha of land and second sowing.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Land processing for sowing

loans.name: Rasul

texts.en:
N. Rasul is a hardworking man who actively contributes to the well-being of his family by selling plant oil in the market. Married with two adult children, Rasul spends many hours at his small stand in the market waiting for his customers. In the traditional Tajik cuisine, the majority of meals are fried or cooked using cottonseed oil. Our national dish, “Pilaw,” needs a great deal of cottonseed oil in order to be delicious. The goods sold by Rasul are in popular demand among the population, so he realizes that with the excellent quality and customer service he gives, he can grow his business. For this reason he is requesting a loan of $2200. Rasul is counting on your help and thanks you for your support.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes: its role as a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous, and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment, forcing hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of plant oil in order to increase the range of goods for selling.

loans.name: Blanca América

texts.es: Blanca América P. C.  vive en municipio de Cojutepeque del departamento de Cuscatlán. Blanca tiene 53 años de edad  vive con su esposo Ricardo y un tío Manuel de 87 años. Blanca posee un negocio de ventas de artesanías llamado ‘‘ Variedades Rosita’’, el cual tiene ya 4 años de existir, se encuentra ubicado en una zona de mucha afluencia ya que a su alrededor esta el parque central de Cojutepeque, municipio muy  visitado como turismo nacional, el crédito que solicita Blanca es para comprar más variedad de adornos para su negocio.
texts.en:
Blanca América P. C. lives in the Cojutepeque municipality in the Cuscatlán department. Blanca is 53, and she lives with her husband, Ricardo, and her Uncle Manuel, 87. Blanca has a business, “Variedades Rosita”, selling handicrafts. She has had the business for four years. It is located in an affluent zone close to the central park of Cojutepeque. It is a municipality that is visited a lot as a national tourism attraction. The loan that Blanca is asking for is to buy a greater variety of decorations for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her business

loans.name: Mrs. Sang Chum Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Thirteen people who live in PO. village in Takeo province make up the village bank loan. The borrowers will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Sang C. is the village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate vegetables. Her husband, Mr. Saor Sek, gathers palm juice to produce palm sugar. Since these two businesses can make only a small income, Mrs. Sang C. decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets to start a pig-breeding business. Mrs. Sang C. has four children:  one is a palm juice collector, another is a firewood cutter and the other two are students. 

Eleven members of this group have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term loans are AMK’s main product because these are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. Such loans allow the borrowers to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy piglets to start a pig-breeding business.

loans.name: Aishat

texts.en: Aishat sells drinks, detergent, provisions, and other items. She is 46 years old and married with 3 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She hopes for a loan of N50000 to purchase more drinks to sell. The demand for her product is high right now.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Munira

texts.en:
I. Munira is 40 years old. She is married and has two children. Munira works cultivating a small farm, which she has done for more than 17 years. She grows different types of vegetables such as beans, onions, and carrots. Every day she gets up very early to work on her land. Munira drives to the produce market in the capital to sell her products, while her son takes care of the daily work on the farm. Munira is very proud of the work she has done together with her beloved son, and grateful that they have been able to acquire the comforts they have in their home. They have made good use of their previous loans. Munira is applying for a loan to IMON International for the fourth time. The loan will be used to buy fertilizer, seeds and insecticides that they need for their farm.    


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.name: Inés De Jesús

texts.es: Inés de Jesús I.  de 39 años de edad, reside en el municipio de Lourdes ubicado en el departamento de La Libertad. Inés tiene 39 años de edad tiene una numerosa familia ya que cuenta con cinco niños todos menores de edad y su esposa María de 31 años. Inés se dedica a su negocio que es una chatarrera donde compra  material como hierro y aluminio que después el clasifica y vende para ser reutilizado en otros productos, Inés solicita este crédito ya que quiere comprar mayor cantidad de chatarra para aprovechar la excelente demanda del producto en este momento, ayudándole a incremetar sus ventas y sus ingresos que es lo único con lo que cuenta toda su familia.
texts.en:
Inés de Jesús I., 30, lives in the Lourdes municipality in the La Libertad department. He has a large family; he has five minor children and his wife, María, 31. Inés is a scrap dealer. He buys material like iron and aluminum. He later sorts and sells it for reuse in other products. Inés is asking for this loan because he wants to buy a larger quantity of scrap metal. He wants to take advantage of the excellent demand for this product at the moment. This will help him increase his sales and his income. His is the sole income for his entire family.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy scrap metal to sell

location.town: Lourdes Colón, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma M. tills a 1.75 hectare rice field in Sto. Nino, South Cotabato. She is 44 years old and has one child. She started working on the farm in 1989. She needs additional capital to run her business, so she joined the CEVI credit program.

She is requesting another loan of Php 12,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizers and chemicals.

CEVI helps her grow her business even more. She can get loans, training and insurance coverage through CEVI.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals

loans.name: Abdurahim

texts.en:
S. Abdurahim is married with three children.  He works in the agriculture and livestock industry. His strength in work is cultivating livestock. Abdurahim has always been dedicated to managing his crops through fumigation and care to obtain a good harvest. Now Abdurahim needs to invest in his livestock business by purchasing cows to raise and to obtain milk for sustenance and to sell. For this reason he seeks support from IMON International by asking for a loan that will allow him to succeed in his business. With your help Abdurahim can get ahead in his business. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of young cattle

loans.name: Zainuramo

texts.ru: Зайнурамо Абдуллоева проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст 35 лет. Замужем, имеет 6 детей. Зайнурамо более 3 лет занимается бизнесом. Она откармливает и продает скот. Муж находится на заработках в России. Кредит просит для закупа теленка, чтобы в дальнейшем продавать ее молоко.
texts.en:
Zainuramo A. lives in the Hamadoni district. She is 35 years old, married and has 6 children. Zainuramo has been an entrepreneur for over 3 years. She feeds and sells livestock. Her husband works in Russia. She is requesting a loan to buy a calf, so that she can sell milk in the future.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a calf

loans.name: Janette

texts.en: Janette B. is 42 years old and makes a living by helping her husband run their two-hectare rice farm. She has applied for this loan from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to increase her farm's yield by buying fertilizers and chemicals. She likes being involved with Community Economic Ventures because it is a way to get training and insurance as well as loans.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and chemicals to increase the yield of her farm

loans.name: Mrs. Mom Chroeng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This loan will help 26 people in Pou village in TaK. province. Mrs. Mom C. has been elected village bank president by the members of this group. She is a farmer who owns a one-hectar field where she grows rice for a living. She faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to hire laborers to work on her field; she is applying for this loan to hire the helpers she needs. Her husband, Mr. Loem Vong, also works on the farm. Mrs. Mom C. is 29 years old and has three children, two of whom attend school while the youngest is too young to work or study. 

Fifteen members of this group have loans with end-of-term payments; the rest make regular monthly payments. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they work best to benefit Cambodia’s poor by allowing them to repay portions of the principal when they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term, and almost all make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva loans.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work on her field.

loans.name: Abdullo

texts.ru: Абдулло Усмонов проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст 37 лет. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Абдулло имеет среднее образование. Он более 10 лет занимается животноводством, т.е. откармливанием и продажей скота. Кредит просит для закупа скота и его продажи, после откармливания.
texts.en:
Abdullo U. lives in the Hamadani district. He is 37 years old, married and has 6 children. Abdullo has a secondary education. He has been involved in animal husbandry, i.e. feeding and selling livestock, for over 10 years. He is requesting a loan for the purchase of livestock and subsequent sale after feeding it.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Rann

texts.en: Mrs. Rann K. was born in 1965 and lives in Svay Thom village in TaK. province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she grows rice. Her husband, Mr. Soeur Saum, is a taxi driver. Mrs. Rann K. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, rice seeds and a plow. She hopes that this loan will allow her to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions. This couple has two children, one of whom works in a garment factory while the other attends a local school. Her husband is seen her in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, rice seeds and a plow.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica makes a living selling sarongs. She is 49 years old, married and has six children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. Veronica is applying for this loan to buy more sarongs to sell. She extends her thanks to all Kiva lenders for their help.

loans.use: To buy more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Uk

texts.en: Mrs. Uk O. lives in Ank Prasat village in Takeo province. She makes her living as a rice farmer, but does not currently have enough money to buy fertilizer or hire laborers to work on her field. She hopes this loan will allow her to do both of these things, and thereby improve her family's living conditions. Mrs. Uk O. is a 58-year-old widow with one child who works in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and hire laborers to work on her field.

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Blessing is 45 years old and a widow with six children. She sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs. She has been in the business for a long time and hopes for the loan amount of N40,000 to purchase more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en: Mrs. Saroeun C. lives in Ank Prasat village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Additionally, she breeds pigs and ducks. Since her breeding business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets and ducklings, and she would use the rest of loan to support the rice field. Her husband, Mr. Art Sok Khom, is a laborer who has been hired to build a well. This couple has four children, all of whom are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy piglets and ducklings, and support the rice field.

loans.name: Sojida

texts.en:
S. Sojida is 42 years old. She is married and has five children. Her husband is currently unemployed. That is why Sojida is the only breadwinner in her family. Sojida sells dried apricots in the central local market. As a rule, she purchases apricots in the market and dries them by herself. She has been in this business for 30 years already. Dried fruit, especially dried apricot, is very popular in Tajikistan. Besides, it is very useful for the health. Considering the constant demand for this kind of goods, the business of Sojida is quite successful and brings a stable income for the family. Today Sojida requests 3000 Somoni. She is going to spend the loan to purchase apricots with the purpose of drying them in order increase the range of goods she sells. Sojida expresses her gratitude for everyone supporting her.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase apricots

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is into tailoring and also sells clothes and shoes. She has been in the business for a long time.

Rose is requesting the loan of N70,000 to purchase more clothes and shoes to sell. She thanks you for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Morn

texts.en:
Mrs. Morn S. was born in 1980 and she lives in Ank Prasat village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn for a living. Her husband, Mr. Tith Pros, is a laborer and the rest of the time he uses to raise ducks. This couple has two children who are attending the local school. Mrs. Morn S.’s husband is shown on the right in the photo.

Mrs. Morn S.’s husband wants to expand his duck-raising business by purchasing more ducklings to raise. Thus, Mrs. Morn S. decided to ask for a loan for her husband’s purpose.

loans.use: To purchase more ducklings for her husband's business

loans.name: Mrs. Pov Sein  Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eight people who live in PO. village in Takeo province make up this village bank loan and they will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Pov S. is the village bank president and she is a farmer who owns a small piece of land for cultivating rice. She is also a fruit seller in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Phun Bin, is a construction worker. Mrs. Pov S. decided to request a loan to buy fruit to resell, and she would use the rest of the money to hire laborers to work on the field. She is a 36-year-old mother of a child who is too young to work or study.   

Seven members in this group loan are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Those with end-of-term loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fruit to resell and for laborers to work on her field.

loans.name: Bose

texts.en: Bose is thirty-three years old and married with four children. She is from Edo State, Nigeria. She sells drinks and provisions. She hopes for a loan of N50000 to purchase more provisions and drinks. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy M. is from the village of Pag-asa, Dumalinao, Zambaonga del sur. She is 40 years old. Mercy is married. To make a living, Mercy owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Mercy has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mercy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mercy is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional piglets for fattening. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Mercy from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional piglets.

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en:
MARJORIE M. is 41 years old, married with 3 teenage children and a resident of Barraks Magallon, in the town of Moises Padilla, Negros Occidental.

She has been a member of NWTF Project Dungganon since 1999. Her sewing business has been the main source of income for her family for the past 6 years, and earns about PHP 5,000.00  (approx. $104) per month, which she frugally budgets to fit the needs of her young family.

For her 16th loan cycle with NWTF-Project Dungganon, she is borrowing PHP 15,000.00 so that she could purchase more clothing materials and sewing supplies to make more clothes to sell to her customers in her community. 

Since she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999, the profits from her business has slowly enabled her to improve their house from a bamboo and nipa hut to a more permanent structure with concrete materials. She has also been setting aside some of her profits in preparation for the college education of her children who are now 13, 15 and 18 years of age.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: the purchase of materials and sewing supplies to increase production capacity of the borrower's business.

loans.name: Ngory

texts.en: Mrs. Ngory Y. is a villager in Leab village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Touch Chantha, sells ice-cream to earn money. Mrs. Ngory Y. is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizer for the field in hopes of making the crop more productive. She would use the rest of the loan to buy some ducklings to raise and breed, and duck food for them. She hopes to increase the family's income and to improve their living conditions with this loan. This couple has a child who is too young to work or study. Her husband and child are presented in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for her rice crop and to buy ducklings.

loans.name: Samit

texts.en: Mrs. Samit Y. lives in Doem Pou village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. She faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to buy rice seed to grow on the field, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed.  She would use the rest of the loan to purchase fertilizer to secure a more productive crop. Her husband, Mr. Nak Phoeun, transports passengers with a horse and cart. Mrs. Samit Y. is thirty-two years old and the mother of four children who are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is also shown in the photo.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria is thirty-five years old and married with five children. She sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs. She hopes for the loan amount of N80000 to purchase more drinks, foodstuffs and provisions to sell. She says thank you for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Luk

texts.en: Mrs. Luk E. is a villager in Prey Mei Lang, Thboung village, in Takeo province. She is a housewife. Her husband, Mr. Som San, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. He faces a problem because he does not have enough money to buy fertilizer or to hire laborers to work in the field. In order to deal with this difficulty, Mrs. Luk E. decided to ask for a loan for her husband’s use. Additionally, she wants to expand her child’s business by purchasing chairs and some ingredients for making the desserts that her child sells. She is forty-six years old and the mother of four childrE., one of whom is the dessert seller. Another attends the local school and the others stay at home to help with housework. Her husband is presented in the picture with her.

loans.use: To support the rice field and to expand her child’s business.

loans.name: Начминисо

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
.

Шарипова Начминисо женщина, которая работает в средней школе учительницей математики. Она кроме своей мало оплачиваемой работы, занимается откормом скота. А продаёт её муж.На следующий кредит Начминисо хочет купить две коровы и корм для них. Сейчас у неё три коровы и маленький телёнок.

loans.use: откорм и продажа скота

loans.name: Fely

texts.en:
Fely Baustista is a fifty-seven-year-old farmer and the mother of seven children. She helps her husband grow rice on their farm in order to provide for their children. Before they were just renting farm land, but because they have produced a better harvest, they were able to buy their own farm, which is a half-hectare in size.

Fely wants a loan of 12,000 PHP from CEVI, one of Kiva's field partners. She will buy fertilizers and chemicals that are badly needed to maximize the harvest.

Because she likes the services of CEVI, Fely still participates in the CEVI cluster meetings. Because of them she has had loans, received training and has insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth M. is a forty-four-year-old married mother of two, Irene and Mathew. She runs a clothes boutique in the busy market of Kongowea in Mombasa. She has been in the boutique business in Mombasa for three years.

This will be Ruth's first time to borrow from KADET, and with the Kenyan shilling 50,000 loan she plans to purchase women's clothes and to refurbish her business premises in order to attract more clients.

In the future Ruth hopes to establish wholesale stores and to become a major supplier of clothes to retailers in Mombasa.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To purchase women's clothes and to refurbish her business premises.

loans.name: Dogo

texts.en:
Dogo R. is thirty-six years old and a married mother of three. She lives with her family in Bamburi, a densely populated town in Mombasa where she runs a charcoal and firewood store. She has been in this business for the last five years.

Dogo is requesting her first loan from KADET, one of Kiva's field partners, and with the money she plans to increase her charcoal and firewood stock. Apart from her charcoal business, Dogo also offers catering services to supplement her income. Her main customers are area residents of Bamburi.

She hopes to own a transport vehicle in the future and also hopes to build a spacious and sheltered store for her stock.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To increase her stock of charcoal and firewood.

loans.name: Teresia Atieno

texts.en:
Teresia O. is thirty-four years old and married to Charles Onyango. Together they have been blessed with four children. She is currently running her tailoring shop at Harambee Market in Western Province.

Teresia came to KADET (one of Kiva's field partners) last year for her first loan after learning about them through a friend. She used that money to add more stock and as a result she got more clients and the profit made was used to pay school fees for her children.

She hopes to use the money from this loan to buy one more sewing machine and to employ someone who will assist her in managing her business.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and hire an employee.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en: Henry owns a computer business center. He is 36 years old and single. He is requesting the loan of N100,000 to purchase more secondhand laptops and other computer accessories to sell. He says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase secondhand laptops and other computer accessories

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia O. is 59 years old, married with 5 adult children, and a resident of Hacienda Danao Ramona, Brgy. Haguimit, La Carlota City. For years, she and her family lived in house made of bamboo with Nipa (palm leaves) for roofing. Her family lived a hand-to-mouth existence: her husband worked in the sugarcane fields of the sugarcane plantation where they lived. During off-season, she and her husband made charcoal to sell. Since she had some knowledge in hairstyling and sewing she supplemented their income by doing odd haircuts and curls, and some sewing on the side. With their determination to move out of poverty, they were able to send all 5 of their children to finish High School.

Alicia joined NWTF- Project Dungganon in October 2002. She used her first loan to put up a small general store, and raised pigs to sell. Later, she and her husband were able to rent a 5-hectare land where they planted sugarcane and rice.  Subsequent loan cycles also enabled her to purchase a carabao and other equipment that they used in their farming ventures. With the profits from farming and her general store she was able to build a concrete house for her family. With  more stable sources of income, she was able to send her 2 youngest children to college until both graduated, but they are currently unemployed and are helping their parents in their business ventures. 

At present Mrs. Alicia is on her 10th Loan Cycle with a loan of PHP 20,000.00. She needs this additional capital to help her purchase additional goods to resell  in her general store.

It is Mrs. Alicia's greatest dream to help her children improve their status in life, and continue breaking the cycle of poverty that she and her husband started in the family by the sweat of their brow.

About NWTF:  
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon

loans.use: Additional goods to resell in thier general store

loans.name: Mrs. Phalla Tuon Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of twenty-five people, is located in Kampong village in TaK. province. Mrs. Phalla T. is the village bank president who has been selected by the other members.

Mrs. Phalla T. is 49 years old and the mother of five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are enrolled in the local school. Mrs. Phalla T. is a farmer who owns 1.5-hectare (3.75-acre) field of land on which she cultivates rice to earn for living. She is also a dried-fish seller in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Bo Sorn, is a teacher in the local school. 

Since her business is doing well, Mrs. Phalla T. wants to expand it by purchasing more dried fish to re-sell to earn more profits for her family. 

Two members in this group loan have end-of-term (EoT) loans and the rest have monthly-payment loans. Those with EOT loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more dried fish to sell to earn more profits for her family

loans.name: Amen

texts.en: Amen is 50 years old and divorced with four children. She has been in the business for a long time. She sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs. She needs a loan of N100000 to purchase more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She thanks all her lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Linet Monyangi

texts.en:
Linet N. is 30 years old, married and blessed with three children. She operates a general store that sells food and household items in Nyamusi Market, which is in Western Province.

She is currently running the business on her own, though at times with the help of her husband, who is a farmer. This is the third loan that Linet is getting from KADET after successfully completing the first and second ones.

Linet hopes to use the money from this loan to expand her business by adding stocks of food and other goods to her store, and even diversify to carrying hardware products. 


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy food and household goods for her general store.

loans.name: Oviawe

texts.en: C. sells provisions and drinks. She is 53 years old and married with five children. She hopes for a loan of N80000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She thanks all her Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is 55 years old and married with four children. She sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs and has been doing this for a long time. She hopes for the loan of N30,000 to purchase more drinks, provisions and foodstuffs. She thanks all her Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Насрулло

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Муминов Насрулло мужчина , который занимается  куплей и откормом скота
Сам работает водителем маршрутного такси. Его доход хватает на жизнь, но для ремонта своего дома ему необходим дополнительный доход. Поэтому прибыль своего бизнеса животноводства он использует на осуществление своих планов. Он благодарен инвесторам  за  понимание и финансирование.

loans.use: откорм и продажа скота

loans.name: Saivali

texts.ru: Сайвали Сулаймонов проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст 39 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Сайвали имеет высшее образование. Он более 4 лет работал "бухгалтером". В данный момент он занимается сельским хозяйством. Он в основном выращивает пшеницу. Кредит просит для покупки удобрения.
texts.en:
Saivali S. lives in the Hamadoni district. He is 39 years old, married and has 4 children. Saivali has a higher education. He spent over 4 years working as an accountant. Currently, he is involved in agriculture. He mainly grows wheat. He is requesting a loan for the purchase of fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizers

loans.name: Parviz

texts.ru: Парвиз Сулаймонов проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст 23 года. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Парвиз имеет высшее образование "юриста". Но Парвиз более 3 лет занимается бизнесом. Он имеет торговую точку, где торгует национальными материалами. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Parviz S. lives in the Hamadoni district. He is 23 years old, married and has 2 children. Parviz has higher education in law. However, Parviz has been involved in business for over 3 years. He has a retail store, where he sells traditional fabrics. He is requesting a loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina is a member of the Itulivu borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 25-year-old woman, is single, and cares for three dependents. 

A year ago, Paulina started her own food business selling fish. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 30,000 Tanzania schillings.

This is Paulina’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more fish for her business. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Paulina hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly operates her store in the downtown city centre of Nairobi. She specializes in making uniforms, clothes and protective garments. She started her business with a loan of Kshs. 20,000 from SMEP in 2007. After repaying, she obtained a second loan of Kshs. 50,000 that she has already repaid.

One of the biggest challenges in her business is servicing orders for large organizations because of the mode of payment. For example, she lost an order because she could not offer a 30-day credit period. She now wants to borrow Ksh. 50,000 to boost her business. She has just received an order to supply uniforms and dust coats to a petroleum firm, but she lacks capital.

loans.use: To be able to service an order to supply uniforms and dust coats .

loans.name: Beatrice Akinyi

texts.en: Beatrice A. runs a hotel in Harambee Market in Western Province. She is 35 years old, married to Michael Ouko, and together they have been blessed with three children. Beatrice's "hotel" is actually a restaurant – "hotel" in Kenyan English most commonly refers to a restaurant, but it can also used to refer to an establishment that offers short-term lodging. After successfully completing her first loan, this is the second loan that Beatrice will be getting from KADET. She hopes to use this money to purchase more cooking equipment and ingredients to enable her to serve her clients with more appetizing meals. She also has a desire to start a retail shop beside her hotel. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy cooking equipment, food and other ingredients for use at her restaurant

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga owns a small grocery store in Nikopol City and has been in this business for fifteen years. She chose food sales because food is something people will always buy.

The store has a good location that brings in many customers. Olga makes sure that her products are always fresh and good quality. She has many repeat and thankful clients and the store brings her a stable income.

Olga would like to borrow 12,100 UAH to purchase more inventory. She has used small business loans before and considers them very helpful.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Larisa

texts.en:
Larisa is married with two children. She sells clothing at an open market in Melitopol City and has been in this business for nine years. Having large experience, she chooses her inventories well, knowing what is going to sell. She enjoys selling women's clothing and has many repeat clients.

Larisa wants to develop her business further. She would like to borrow 12,000 UAH to increase her summer assortment. Larisa is a very responsible person. She always pays her loans on time.

loans.use: To increase her assortment

loans.name: Halleluiah Group

texts.en:
Joseph is thirty-five years old. He is married and has children. He is an artisan. Joseph is the leader of a trust bank group called "Halleluiah." He is the young man seated in the group photograph. The members of this group are mostly traders, food vendors, and farmers.

They buy their raw materials, wares, or goods from Kumasi, and sometimes from nearby communities, and sell at the market square in their community. Some of them trek to other towns to sell on their market days as well. The members have been in business for some time and have amassed a great deal of experience in their businesses. In this group, the members guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan. They are requesting the loan to procure more goods, to be able to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Nyame Ne Hene Group

texts.en: Victoria is thirty-seven years old. She is married and has given birth to two children who are currently in school. She is a trader. Victoria deals in footwear and textiles. She hawks to sell. She is the leader of a trust bank group called "Nyame Ne Hene," which literally means "God is the King." She is seated in front in the group photograph. The members of this group are mostly traders, food vendors, and farmers. They work very hard to support their spouses and to provide for their families. They buy their raw materials, wares, or goods from Kumasi, and sometimes from nearby communities, and sell at the market square in the community they live in. Some trek to other towns to sell their products. The members have been in business for some time and have amassed a great deal of experience in their businesses. They guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan. They are requesting the loan to procure more goods and raw materials to be able to expand their businesses and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Anthony's Group

texts.en: Anthony is twenty-seven years old. He is married and has no children at the moment. He is a trader. He deals in game meat. He supplies local chop bar operators. Anthony is the leader of a trust bank group called "Shalom." He is the young man seated in front in the group photograph. The members of this group are mostly traders, food vendors, and farmers. They work very hard to support their spouses and to provide for their families. They buy their raw materials, wares, or goods from Kumasi, and sometimes from nearby communities, and sell at the market square in the community they live in. Some trek to other towns to sell their products. The members have been in business for some time and have amassed a great deal of experience in their businesses. They guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan. They are requesting the loan to procure more goods and raw materials to be able to expand their businesses and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Mena

texts.en:
Behind the court at Elmina, Mena A. sells banku, which she prepares with cassava and corn flour, and fried fish with pepper. She has been selling banku and fried fish with pepper, since 1995.

Mena has no educational background. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a secretary. Mena is responsible for paying utility bills and also payment of her children’s school fees.

Mena’s loan will be used to buy more maize, fish oil and pepper to cook for sale at the market. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest in her business and to save the rest.

loans.use: To buy more maize, fish oil and pepper to cook for sale at the market

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en:
Benedicta A. N. sells gari (couscous-like grain made from grated cassava), second-hand clothing, peppers and tomatoes in Elmina. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a mason. Benedicta has received a senior high school education.

Benedicta has been selling gari, second-hand clothing, peppers and tomatoes since 2005. She is responsible for paying the light bills. Her loan will be used to increase her capital to buy more gari and second-hand clothing to sell. She hopes to reinvest the new profits in her business.

loans.use: To buy gari and second-hand clothing to sell

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort V. is married and has two children. Her husband is a driver. She has received schooling through primary school.

Comfort makes and sells palm kernel oil at Atabadze near Elmina, which she has done since 1995. She uses her income for paying school fees and other expenses.

Comfort will use the loan to purchase more palm kernels to make oil for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Comfort plans to save towards buying a new house.

loans.use: To purchase more palm kernels to make oil for sale

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis T. sells material, thread, pins, buttons, and so on at Elmina. He has received a senior high school education. He is married and has four children. His wife is a trader.

Francis has been selling since 1994 and is responsible for paying his children’s school fees and other utility bills. His loan will be used to buy more materials for sale. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to reinvest in his business and also to save the rest.

loans.use: To buy to buy more materials for sale

loans.name: Efuah

texts.en:
Efuah S. is married and has three children. She has received schooling through primary school level. Her husband is a timber contractor.

Efuah sells doughnuts which she makes with flour, margarine and other ingredients at Terterim near Elmina, which she has done since 2008. Efuah uses her income to cater for her grandchildren’s education.

Efuah will use the loan to purchase flour, sugar and oil to fry her doughnuts for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save towards building a new house.

loans.use: To purchase flour, sugar and oil to fry her doughnuts for sale

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce M. is married and has four children. She has received schooling through primary school. Joyce has been making and selling palm kernel oil in Ataabadze near Elmina since 2001. Her husband is a cleaner. Joyce uses her income to help her husband to pay for their children's school fees.

Joyce will use the loan to buy more palm kernel to make oil to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Joyce plans to buy more palm kernel to process and sell.

loans.use: Joyce will use the loan to buy more palm kernel

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en:
Philomena E. sells smoked fish at Terterim near Elmina. She has no educational background. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a fisherman.

Philomena has been in this business since 1995 and is responsible for the upkeep of her family. Her loan will be used to buy more fish for processing before selling at the market. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest in her business and also to save the rest.

loans.use: To buy more fish for processing before selling at the market

loans.name: Alex

texts.en: Alex is newly married and runs a stationery business with a family member. He also provides typing and photocopy services. He supplies stationery to the schools in the rural areas. His major challenge is transporting the stationery to these schools. He has been in this business, which has big potential for growth, for the past two years. The stationery business is a big market in Kenya and is dominated by big players who able to undercut prices and squeeze the margins for the small players. However, Alex has discovered a niche market in the rural areas. He is now requesting a loan of Kshs 50,000 to buy more stationery for the needy schools.

loans.use: To buy more stationery to be supplied to institutions in the rural areas

loans.name: Khalil

texts.en: Khalil is a 45-year-old married man with four children. In 2008, he decided to open his own furniture carpentry shop to satisfy the needs of the market in his village. Today, Khalil is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase tools in order to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools in order to expand his business

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena K. makes and sells palm kernel oil at Elmina. She has received a junior high school education. She is married and has one child. Her husband is a driver.

Helena has been selling palm kernel oil since 2006 and is responsible for the upkeep of her home. Her loan will be used to buy more palm kernels to make the oil and then sell it. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest into her business and also to save the rest.

loans.use: To buy more palm kernels to make the oil and then sell it

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a widow who has three children. Two of her children are still in school (one in secondary school and one in college). She operates a café in the city centre and usually serves food and tea to all the staff within her premises. Her major challenge is space, because patrons cannot fit in and they are forced to eat while standing. She aspires to open a big restaurant where all her customers can relax enjoy their meals. She is requesting a loan of Ksh. 50,000 to buy a microwave and a refrigerator.

loans.use: Buy refrigerator and microwave

loans.name: Farouk

texts.en: Farouk is a 36-year-old married man with 2 children. He has been working as a painter since 2001 to improve living conditions for his family. Today, Farouk is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000 to purchase an air compressor to expand his work.

loans.use: to purchase an air compressor

loans.name: Leila

texts.en: Leila is a 48-year-old married woman with 3 children. She has been working as a tailor for the past 20 years and has become known in the neighboring villages. After this long experience in this field, Leila is requesting to borrow US$ 1,200 in order to buy a sewing machine to provide a variety of products for her clientele.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en: Bilal is a 19-year-old man living with his parents. In 2007, he decided to open an accessories shop as his own business. Today, Bilal is requesting to borrow US$ 900 to purchase merchandise in order to satisfy the demand of the market  and increase his income.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise

loans.name: Kinyajui

texts.en: K. is a subsistence farmer who grows wheat and maize. He has three children. With the little money that  he earned from the sale of wheat in 2008, he opened a Jaspen Auto shop where he sells spare parts for motor bikes and bicycles. He says that the demand for these spares has gone up since the government eliminated the tax on imported motorbikes. He is now seeking a loan of kshs. 50,000 to buy more spare parts for the motorbikes. His aspires to start and manage his own transport services.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for motobikes

loans.name: Nouhad

texts.en: Nouhad is a 28-year-old married man living with his wife.  In 2001, he decided to open his own barber shop in his village to begin a new career. After 13 years in the business, he has decided to expand his business by purchasing merchandise for his shop; that is why he is requesting to borrow US$ 800.

loans.use: purchasing merchandise to sell in his barber shop

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 28-year-old man, engaged to be married and presently living with his parents. After 13 years of experience, he decided to open a furniture-making shop in 2008 as a private business to improve his life conditions and be able to get married to his fiancée. Today, Mohamad is requesting to borrow US$ 1,200 to purchase textiles to satisfy the need of his clients.

loans.use: to purchase textiles

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther has a strong desire to create job opportunities. Started started her own business at the age of 23 years. Esther runs a printing business on Mfangano Street in Nairobi. She has been in this business for 3 years and now wants to expand the business. Her dream is to own a printing press. Her current printer is obsolete and she wants to replace it with a new one. She wants to borrow Kshs. 50,000 to purchase a new printer. Although she is still single, her parents and siblings depend on her for all of their financial needs.

loans.use: Buy a new printer

loans.name: Maya

texts.en: Maya is a 26-year-old married woman. She has been working as a home-based hairdresser since 2008; she has clients from the neighboring villages. Today, Maya is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000 to buy additional tools and equipment to expand her job.

loans.use: to buy additional tools and equipment

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en: Nicholas is married and blessed with two children. He runs a small errands business in the central business district. He currently has one employee and wants to employ two more people. He has been in this business for two years and wants to expand it. He now wants a loan of Ksh. 50,000 to buy a motorbike. With a motorbike, he will be able to double his revenue because he can run many errands each day.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas A. sells clothing in Elmina. Dorcas has received a senior high school education.  She is married and has two children; her husband is a teacher. Dorcas has been selling clothing since 1996. She is responsible for paying her utility bills and other expenses for her family. Her loan will be used to buy more dresses to sell. She hopes to reinvest some of the new profits from her business and to save the rest.

loans.use: To buy more dresses for resale

loans.name: Adom Wo Wiem Group

texts.en:
Sylvia is forty-six years old. She is married and has given birth to four children who are all currently in school. She is a petty trader.

Sylvia runs a cold store. She supplies mostly to food vendors. Sylvia is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Adom wo wiem’ which literally means 'Grace is from Above'. She is seated in front in the group photograph. The members of this group are mostly petty traders, food vendors and or farmers. They work very hard to help their spouses provide for their families. They buy their raw materials or goods from Kumasi and sometimes from nearby communities and sell at the market square in the community they live in. Some trek to other towns to sell their products.

The members have been in business for some time and have amassed a great deal of experience in their businesses. They guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan. They are requesting the loan to procure more goods and raw materials to be able to expand their businesses and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en:
After years of working jobs that didn’t inspire him, at 25, Josh finally decided to pursue his own ideas. Josh runs a web-based used/new clothing company. In 2008, he took a big step and made his business his sole source of income. He sifts through the racks of thrift stores in his town of Lansing, Michigan, buying up all the name brands and new clothing he can get his hands on.

Currently Josh processes about 300 orders per month but he would like to increase that to four or five hundred. After learning that Kiva had opened up to US businesses, Josh applied for a loan at ACCION USA online and was approved for $1,000. He has never taken a loan from a bank, this is his first time accessing capital for his business. With his loan Josh is going to do a sweep of the thrift stores in his town, buying clothing to increase his inventory.

Talking to Josh, you learn that he is ambitious about running his own business and being successful. He has been taking business classes at the local community college and has many great new business ideas. In the near future, he would like to develop a monthly clothing subscription where clients would receive three items of clothing each month.

loans.use: buying new and used clothing for resale

loans.name: Rehema Musoke‘S Group

texts.en:
Rehema is the leader of a four-member group. She is 48 years old and married with five children, aged between 17 and 25 years. Only three of her children go to school. She resides in and owns a four-roomed house where she lives with five people.

Rehema takes care of ten additional family members. There is no electricity or piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala.

Rehema stays in Mulago Katanga zone selling bananas and water in Kalerwe, one of Kampala's suburbs. She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping. Besides the banana business, Rehema also sells chicken and pig feed. She sells to an average of 20 people a day and sells to all categories of people, excluding children. She works six days a week.

Rehema sells mainly retail. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent for her business premises. She has been in this business for the last 15 years. Rehema has been with MCDT for over five years and is servicing her tenth loan, working with the same group-mates. She wants to use this loan to buy bananas. Regina is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning permanent business premises.

loans.use: To buy more bananas

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph A. is married and has four children. His wife is a fishmonger. Joseph has no educational status.

Joseph sells fresh fish at Elmina, which he has done since 2000. Joseph uses his income to pay school fees and other expenses.

Joseph will use the loan to purchase more fish for sale. With the new profits from his expanded business, Joseph plans to further his children’s education and also to save the rest.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for sale

loans.name: Hector Javier

texts.es: El señor Héctor P. tiene 31 años de edad, vive en la comarca de San Cayetano del municipio de Villa del Carmen, Departamento de Managua, casado su esposa ama de casa, tiene dos hijos de nueve años y dos meses, viven en casa propia, trabaja como mecánico automotriz en la Alcaldía de Villa del Carmen desde hace seis meses, anteriormente trabaja en un taller de mecánica. Como necesidad primordial es la seguridad de su familia, por lo cual se le ha presentado dificultades por falta de financiamiento. Gracias al préstamo en Afodenic lograra comprar materiales de construcción como: cemento, ventana, piso para la construcción de un anexo ala vivienda y poder estar en mejores condiciones.
texts.en:
Mr. Héctor P. is 31 years old, and lives in the San Cayetano district in the municipality of Villa del Carmen, the department of Managua. He is married and his wife is a housewife. They have two children; one is 9 and one is two months. They live in their own home. He has worked for six months as an auto mechanic in the town of Villa del Carmen. Before this, he worked in a mechanical workshop.

Providing security for your family is a basic human need, but this has been difficult for him because of lack of finances. Thanks to a loan from AFODENIC, he will be able to buy construction materials like cement, windows, and flooring to construct an addition to his house and to be able to live in better conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Iverson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials to build a room

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina O. is married and has two children. Her husband is a physician. Faustina has received an education.

Faustina sells porridge and smoked fish at Elmina, which he has done since 1999. She uses her income to support her husband in paying for their children’s school fees.

Faustina will use the loan to purchase more fish for processing before selling them at the market and also to buy maize and beans to prepare her porridge which she sells in the morning. With the new profits from her expanded business, Faustina plans to save and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for processing and to buy maize and beans to prepare her porridge

loans.name: Nyame Som Pa Group

texts.en:
M. is forty years old. He is married and has nine children who are all still in school. He is a petty trader. He sells cereals. He supplies to local food vendors.

M. is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Nyame Som Pa’. He is the man seated in front in the group photograph. The members of this group are mostly traders, food vendors and/or farmers. They work very hard to help their spouses provide for their families. They buy their raw materials or goods from Kumasi and sometimes from nearby communities and sell at the market square in the community they live in. Some trek to other towns to sell their products.

The members have been in business for some time and have amassed a great deal of experience in their businesses. They guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan. They are requesting the loan to procure more goods and raw materials to be able to expand their businesses and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua E. sells smoked fish at Elmina. She has received no formal education. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a tailor.

Ekua has been selling smoked fish since 1993 and is responsible for the upkeep of the house. Her loan will be used to buy more fish to process for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest in her business and also to save the rest for future use.

loans.use: To buy more fish to process for sale

loans.name: Maynor Agustin

texts.es: El señor Maynor A. tiene 26 años, casado su esposa ama de casa, tiene un hijo de dos años, vive en la comunidad de Villa del Carmen del municipio de Managua, los planes a acorto plazo es las mejoras a su casa y a largo plazo un mejor trabajo con mayores prestaciones. Trabaja en la alcaldía de Villa del Carmen en el cargo de guardia de seguridad desde hace seis meses, antes trabajaba en diferentes proyectos como obrero. El ha encontrado muchas dificultades para la terminación de su vivienda por financiamiento. Gracias Afodenic lograra comprar materiales de construcción como: cemento, hierro, zinc. Obteniendo protección y seguridad para su familia.
texts.en:
Maynor A. is 26 and married. His wife is a housewife. They have a two year old son. They live in the Villa del Carmen community of the Managua municipality. His short-term plan is to make improvements to their house. His long-term plan is to get better work with larger loans. He works in the mayor’s office in Villa del Carmen. He has been a security guard there for six months. He previously worked on different projects as a laborer. He has encountered several financial difficulties in finishing his house. Thanks to Afodenic, he will be able to buy construction materials like cement, iron, and zinc. That way he will obtain protection and safety for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy material

loans.name: Kofi

texts.en:
Kofi T. is married and has four children. His wife is a fish monger. He has received schooling through primary school.

Kofi sells fresh fish at Elmina, which he has done since 1995. He uses his income for paying his children’s school fees. He will use the loan to repair his machine and also to increase his capital to buy more fish for sale.
